title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals. The Act allows for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals and notifying the state judicial branch or agency of the amount collected. If an offset is made on a joint return, the notice must include the names and taxpayer identification numbers of each filer. The Act allows for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals. The names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses of each person filing the return must be included. Priorities for offsetting overpayments include liabilities for internal revenue tax, past-due support, debts owed to a Federal agency, and other legally enforceable debts. The Act allows for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals. Overpayments will be applied to debts owed to Federal agencies, State income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited to future federal tax liabilities. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or judicial branches, overpayments will be applied to those debts. The Act allows for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals. Overpayments will be applied to debts owed to Federal agencies, State income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited to future federal tax liabilities. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or judicial branches, overpayments will be applied to those debts in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for notice and evidence consideration. Past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt refers to debts resulting from judgments or sentences in courts handling criminal or traffic cases in the State. State judicial debt refers to debts from court cases in the State, including court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims. The debt must be past-due and assessed by a competent jurisdiction handling criminal or traffic cases. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts, specifying required information and types of debts eligible for reduction. State agencies may need to pay a fee for this procedure. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts, specifying required information and types of debts eligible for reduction. Any fee paid to the Secretary for this procedure will be used to reimburse appropriations. States must promptly repay any erroneous payments made to them by the Secretary. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under subsections (c), (d), (e), (f), or (g) of section 6402. Conforming amendments are made to sections 6402(a), 6402(d)(2), and 6402(e)(3)(B) to include subsection (g) for reducing overpayments. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under subsections (c), (d), (e), (f), or (g) of section 6402. Paragraph (2)(B) of section 6402(f) is amended to specify the process before overpayment is reduced or credited for State judicial debts and future Federal tax liabilities. The amendments made by this Act apply to refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008, allowing disclosure of information for reduction under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code.
